intro: Piqueria pittieri, commonly known as the Mexican pricklypoppy, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its spiny stems and showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds. Piqueria pittieri is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid environments.
